body.text: <html><head><style>*,::after,::before{box-sizing:border-box}*{margin:0}body,html{height:100%}body{line-height:1.5;-webkit-font-smoothing:antialiased;margin:50px}canvas,img,picture,svg,video{display:block;max-width:100%}button,input,select,textarea{font:inherit}h1,h2,h3,h4,h5,h6,p{overflow-wrap:break-word}#__next,#root{isolation:isolate}.page-break{page-break-after:always}</style></head><body><div class="coverPage blue"><div class="innerContent"><div class="subtitle"><p><span style="font-size:24px">LESSON ONE</span></p></div><div class="title"><p><span style="font-size:64px">ASSESSING YOUR STRESS</span></p></div><div class="description"><p><span style="font-size:24px">Stress is not something that should be taken lightly. Are you feeling stressed? Find out your stress level with our short quiz.</span></p></div></div><div class="footer"><p>UP NEXT: ALL ABOUT STRESS</p></div></div><p><br></p><div class="page-break"></div><div class="titleBar blue"><span style="font-style:normal;font-size:24px">LESSON ONE: ASSESSING YOUR STRESS</span></div><div class="twoColumn"><div class="column"><div><span style="font-size:18px"><b>Understanding Your Stress&nbsp;<br></b></span><span style="font-size:16px">Most people experience continuous stress in the form of daily hassles, relationship troubles, problems at work, chronic illness, or other external life events. Have you ever wondered why some people are devastated by this stress, while others are relatively unaffected? Or why some people thrive in high-pressure, driven work environments while others self-destruct?</span></div><div><span style="font-size:16px"><br></span></div><div><span style="font-size:16px">Beliefs, values, personality, support, and self esteem are a few factors that play a role in how someone handles stress. Some of these factors are hard to control, but many can be adjusted to help you deal with stress more effectively.&nbsp;</span><br><br></div><div class="callout"><p style="text-align:center"><span style="font-size:36px">How do you handle stress? Some factors are beyond your control, but many can be adjusted so you deal with it more effectively.&nbsp;</span></p></div></div><div class="column"><p><img src="https://benovate-images.s3-us-west-2.amazonaws.com/e6ae407ae1e7f2a382a16cf1a1663b13Lesson1.1edit.jpg" style="width:100%"></p><p><span style="font-size:16px">Chronic stress can be dangerous and is not something to be taken lightly. It can cause significant health issues if steps aren’t taken to help get it under control. However, there is good news here! You can learn to skillfully handle stress and even prevent the kind of toxic stress that can cause major health issues. In this course, you will gain a better understanding of where your stress levels currently rank, more detailed information about stress, and strategies to help manage or address the stress you may be experiencing in your daily life.&nbsp;</span></p></div></div><div class="logoFooter blue"></div><p><br></p><div class="page-break"></div><div class="titleBar blue"><span style="font-style:normal;font-size:24px">LESSON ONE: ASSESSING YOUR STRESS</span></div><div class="twoColumn"><div class="column"><p><img src="https://benovate-images.s3-us-west-2.amazonaws.com/495f4b80d8c4c26f8434b43c69d79e5aLesson%201.2%20edit%203.jpg" style="width:100%"></p></div><div class="column"><div><p><b><span style="font-size:18px">How Stressed Are You?&nbsp;<br></span></b><span style="font-size:16px">You’d be surprised by how many people aren’t fully aware of their current state of stress. Just becoming aware of your reality can jump-start the process of stress reduction and movement toward better health.&nbsp;</span></p></div><div class="callout"><p style="text-align:center"><span style="font-size:30px">It’s important to remember that you can’t always control the stress that you experience, but you can control how you react and manage your stress.</span></p></div></div></div><div class="logoFooter blue"></div><p><br></p><div class="page-break"></div><div class="titleBar blue"><span style="font-size:24px;font-style:normal">LESSON ONE: ASSESSING YOUR STRESS</span><br></div><p><span style="font-size:16px">Take a moment to answer a few questions about things that may contribute to increased stress levels.</span></p><p><span style="font-size:16px"><i>Keep track of how many times you answer<b>“yes,”</b>and you’ll find out how likely you are to have risks of health issues related to stress.&nbsp;</i></span><br></p><ol><li><span style="font-size:16px">Are you feeling stressed right now?</span></li><li><span style="font-size:16px">Do you have trouble sleeping due to worrying about problems with work, relationships, finances, etc.?</span></li><li><span style="font-size:16px">In the past few months have you been smoking, drinking, or eating more to try to cope with things going on in your life?</span></li><li><span style="font-size:16px">Do you suffer from anxiety or depression?</span></li><li><span style="font-size:16px">Do you feel like you have no one or very few people to turn to if you need to talk?</span></li><li><span style="font-size:16px">Are you inactive (exercising very little, or not at all?</span></li><li><span style="font-size:16px">Are you overweight?</span></li><li><span style="font-size:16px">Do you suffer from regular indigestion, ulcers, or digestive issues, probably related to stress?</span></li><li><span style="font-size:16px">Do you find yourself easily irritated with small things?</span></li><li><span style="font-size:16px">Do you frequently feel like there's not enough time in the day to get things done?</span></li><li><span style="font-size:16px">Do you have a low level of job satisfaction?</span></li><li><span style="font-size:16px">Do you think you're a workaholic (or would others classify you as that)?</span></li><li><span style="font-size:16px">Have you missed work more than 5 days due to illness in the past year?</span></li><li><span style="font-size:16px">Have you recently had something unexpected happen, causing stresses you normally don't have to deal with?</span></li><li><span style="font-size:16px">Are you going through a break up, divorce, or separation?</span></li><li><span style="font-size:16px">Are you planning a wedding?</span></li><li><span style="font-size:16px">Have you recently added to your family, are you planning to soon, or struggling with fertility issues?</span></li><li><span style="font-size:16px">Have you recently experienced a major change in responsibilities or new position?</span></li><li><span style="font-size:16px">Do you feel like you usually don't have enough time to relax or take time for yourself?</span></li><li><span style="font-size:16px">Have you experienced any physical symptoms due to worry or stress (dry mouth, shaking, excessive sweating, fear, tension headache, panic)?</span></li><li><span style="font-size:16px">Do you feel like you are frequently struggling with money?</span></li><li><span style="font-size:16px">Do you neglect to practice relaxation techniques during times of stress?</span></li></ol><p><span style="font-size:16px"><br></span></p><p><span style="font-size:16px">Continue onto the next page to see where your stress levels fall.</span></p><div class="logoFooter blue"></div><p><span style="font-size:16px"><br></span></p><div class="page-break"></div><div class="titleBar blue"><span style="font-style:normal;font-size:24px">LESSON ONE: ASSESSING YOUR STRESS</span></div><p><span style="font-size:18px"><b>Stress Assessment Results</b></span></p><p><span style="color:#94bd7b;font-weight:700;font-size:18px">Low Stress 0-7&nbsp;<br></span><span style="font-size:16px">Based on your answers, you seem to be experiencing a</span><span style="font-size:16px;font-weight:700">pretty healthy or manageable amount of stress</span><span style="font-size:16px">. Everyone experiences some form of stress on a daily basis. It’s still important to take time for yourself and practice relaxation techniques to manage the stressors that you do have. Stress is unavoidable and your levels can change drastically with any major events or life changes, so it is still important to learn coping strategies for when those things happen in your life.</span></p><p><span style="color:#ffd663;font-weight:700;font-size:18px">Moderate Stress 8-12&nbsp;<br></span><span style="font-size:16px">Based on your answers, you seem to be experiencing<span style="font-weight:700">higher than average</span>amounts of stress in your life right now. Some people can handle this level of stress pretty easily by taking a little more time for some stress management techniques. Some people may experience difficulties with this level of stress, especially if they let it build up and don’t make an effort to get it under control. Start adding some techniques from this course into your daily life or contact a mental health professional if you feel you need additional help</span>.</p><p><span style="color:#e76363;font-weight:700;font-size:18px">High Stress 13-22&nbsp;<br></span><span style="font-size:16px">Based on your answers, you seem to be experiencing</span><span style="font-size:16px;font-weight:700">very high levels of stress</span><span style="font-size:16px">in your life right now. This is likely causing physical or other negative effects on your body and in your life and you may be too overwhelmed to deal with it properly. Make it a priority to start to implement more stress relieving techniques from this course into your daily routine, and we recommend seeking professional guidance if you feel like it’s too much to deal with on your own.</span></p><div class="logoFooter blue"></div><p><br></p><div class="page-break"></div><div class="titleBar blue"><span style="font-style:normal;font-size:24px">LESSON ONE: ASSESSING YOUR STRESS</span></div><div class="twoColumn"><div class="column"><div><p><span style="font-weight:700;font-size:18px"><span style="font-size:18px">W</span><span style="font-size:18px">hat Stresses You Out</span></span><span style="font-weight:700;font-size:18px"><span style="font-size:18px">?<br></span>&nbsp;</span><span style="font-size:16px">In order to manage your stress properly, it’s important to first identify the sources of stress in your life. Take a moment to write down or think about all of the stressors you are dealing with.</span></p></div><div class="callout"><p style="text-align:center"><span style="font-size:20px">Some common stressors include:</span></p><p style="text-align:center"><span style="font-weight:400"><span style="font-size:24px">Job changes</span><br></span></p><p style="text-align:center"><span style="font-weight:400;font-size:24px">Workplace stress</span></p><p style="text-align:center"><span style="font-weight:400;font-size:24px">Family or relationship conflicts</span></p><p style="text-align:center"><span style="font-weight:400;font-size:24px">Staying healthy</span></p><p style="text-align:center"><span style="font-weight:400;font-size:24px">Loneliness</span></p><p style="text-align:center"><span style="font-weight:400;font-size:24px">Financial troubles</span></p><p style="text-align:center"><span style="font-weight:400;font-size:24px">Pain or chronic diseases</span></p><p style="text-align:center"><span style="font-weight:400;font-size:24px">Traffic or environment stress</span></p><p style="text-align:center"><span style="font-weight:400;font-size:24px">Travel or holidays</span></p><p style="text-align:center"><span style="font-weight:400;font-size:24px">Upcoming wedding</span></p><p style="text-align:center"><span style="font-weight:400;font-size:24px">Economy</span></p><p style="text-align:center"><span style="font-weight:400;font-size:24px">Unpredictable events</span></p><p style="text-align:center"><span style="font-weight:400;font-size:24px">Beliefs or fears</span></p></div></div><div class="column"><p></p><p><img src="https://benovate-images.s3-us-west-2.amazonaws.com/a91d2855780f0db3a29bc6d00e3a0e79Lesson%201.6%20edit.jpg" style="width:100%"><span style="font-size:16px"></span></p><p><span style="font-size:16px">There may be one major thing in your life that is causing most of your stress, or you may have multiple factors causing you an equal amount of stress (possibly even additional since you are trying to juggle so many things). In addition to identifying common sources of stress, you may want to take it a step further to identify the specific situation causing stress. For example if you identified workplace stress, think about what exactly causes stress in the workplace. Is it a specific coworker? Is it certain tasks? Knowing specifics allows for better stress management.</span></p></div></div><div class="logoFooter blue"></div><p><br></p><div class="page-break"></div><div class="titleBar blue"><span style="font-style:normal;font-size:24px">LESSON ONE: ASSESSING YOUR STRESS</span></div><div class="twoColumn"><div class="column"><p><img src="https://benovate-images.s3-us-west-2.amazonaws.com/835a0ac245bb05b6d0e5cef0e4893107Lesson%201.7%20edit.png" style="width:100%"></p></div><div class="column"><p><span style="font-size:16px">Picture a box with four sections. For each of your stressors, ask yourself if it is important and if it is something you can control.</span></p><p><span style="font-size:16px">Work on&nbsp;<span style="font-weight:700">letting go</span>&nbsp;of the stressors that aren’t that important to you. Try to&nbsp;<span style="font-weight:700">address stressors</span>&nbsp;that are important to you that you have some control over. Also, be sure to&nbsp;<span style="font-weight:700">use stress management techniques</span>&nbsp;or limit exposure to stressors that are important but out of your control.&nbsp;</span><span style="font-size:16px"></span></p><p><span style="font-size:16px"><a href="https://benovate-images.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/2021_Identify+Stressors.pdf" target="_blank">Click here</a>for a PDF version of this activity if you would like to explore it at a later time or print out a copy to fill out.</span></p></div></div><div class="logoFooter blue"></div><span style="font-size:10px">Sources Referenced:</span><br><ol style="font-size:10px"><li>&nbsp;U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs. (2014, December). Manage stress workbook. Retrieved from https://www.prevention.va.gov/mpt/2013/docs/managestressworkbook_dec2013.pdf.</li></ol><div class="page-break"></div><div class="coverPage blue"><div class="innerContent"><div class="subtitle"><p><span style="font-size:36px">Congratulations</span></p></div><div class="title"><span style="font-size:55px">You've completed Lesson One and earned 10 points!</span></div><div class="description"><p><span style="font-size:24px">Next up in Lesson Two, you'll gain a deeper understanding of stress and how it works.</span></p><p><span style="font-size:24px"><br></span></p><p><span style="font-size:12px"><i>Note: Redeem the Lesson One Card within your regular Card stream. All other Lessons will auto-redeem.</i></span></p></div></div><div class="footer"><p><br></p></div></div><p><br></p></body></html&gt
